Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is a direct result of a funded NST TCUP Planning Grant. It has been determined that recruitment,
retention, and research are the greatest needs. Students at SCC will build its capacity to offer
STEM disciplines through reformed STEM coursework, research, and internship activities. The
proposed activity will yield data which will assist SCC in STEM enhancement. This approach
will also provide facilitate matriculation of our two-year graduates into a four year institution of
higher education or the job market. Faculty will develop a research base and research agenda,
which will involve all SCC students, faculty members, and other tribal programs.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the reporting period form 12/01/2012-06/30/2013 the
Stone Child College (SCC)
STEM Project # 0631817 the major project outcomes and findings include a
partnership with Salish Kootenai College (SKC).  SCC is currently laying the foundation for offering a four year degree program in Social Work through SKC and SCC is reviewing other STEM programs to further develop that partnership to offer more four degree opportunities for SCC students with the help of SKC, where our students will completed their associates degree at SCC and will continue with their Bachelor’s degree at SKC and those classes will be offered on the SCC campus via SKC instructors or online and hybrid when needed.  Throughout the project year’s our STEM fields have shown a significant increase in graduation rates currently 47% of our graduates are from the STEM fields, we also have successful transfer students.  SCC has also established a Moodle website that is used by STEM staff and also has redeveloped their cultural Ethnobotany class.  Many of the STEM classes have been updated and improved to go along with the transferabilty inititiave with the Montana Univeristy System.  For this reporting period the NSF TCUP program had 24 students total throughout Summer, Fall and Spring semesters, ouf of the 24 students 10 graduated within the academic year.  Students have went on to Montana State University-Northern, University of Montana and to Salish Kootenai College to pursue bachelor's degrees.    


Last Modified: 10/01/2013
Modified by: Cory L Sangrey
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: For the reporting period form 12/01/2012-06/30/2013 the Stone Child College (SCC) STEM Project # 0631817 the major project outcomes and findings include a partnership with Salish Kootenai College (SKC). SCC is currently laying the foundation for offering a four year degree program in Social Work through SKC and SCC is reviewing other STEM programs to further develop that partnership to offer more four degree opportunities for SCC students with the help of SKC, where our students will completed their associates degree at SCC and will continue with their BachelorÆs degree at SKC and those classes will be offered on the SCC campus via SKC instructors or online and hybrid when needed. Throughout the project yearÆs our STEM fields have shown a significant increase in graduation rates currently 47% of our graduates are from the STEM fields, we also have successful transfer students. SCC has also established a Moodle website that is used by STEM staff and also has redeveloped their cultural Ethnobotany class. Many of the STEM classes have been updated and improved to go along with the transferabilty inititiave with the Montana Univeristy System. For this reporting period the NSF TCUP program had 24 students total throughout Summer, Fall and Spring semesters, ouf of the 24 students 10 graduated within the academic year. Students have went on to Montana State University-Northern, University of Montana and to Salish Kootenai College to pursue bachelor's degrees. Last Modified: 10/01/2013 Submitted by: Cory L Sangrey
